post_text: Margaretta Local Schools has been approved to offer free breakfasts/lunches to all community members up to the age of 18. Starting Monday, September 14, we will offer a pickup line for all lunches on Mondays ONLY from 10:30 am -11:30 am for all remote students and non-attending members and 11:30 am - 12:30 pm for all hybrid students. The pickup line will be at the Elementary parent pickup/dropoff loop. Arrangements can be made should you not be available during the stated pick up times offered. If your child is a hybrid schedule student they will receive three breakfasts/lunches. If your child is a remote schedule student they will receive five breakfasts/lunches. For breakfasts/lunches that have already been charged to your students account since the start of the 2020-2021 school year, their lunch account will be credited. You are not required to sign up for this offer. This program is being subsidized by the Federal USDA and is currently being funded through the end of December.

Attention 6th Grade Parents:

Because of our hybrid, then remote, start to the school year, we will not be starting 6th grade band and choir as usual at the beginning of September. In their place, we will offer a Music Ensemble Training course to prepare students for band and choir. This course will teach students notes and rhythms, instruments and voices, as well as expose them to different musical ensembles and styles. Once we are back to school either in a hybrid or traditional setting, we will identify those students who wish to participate in band and give them information about renting instruments. We will then enroll them in band. Students who choose not to join band will be enrolled in the 6th grade choir. We ask for your patience during the start of this school year and we look forward to working with your students!

Winners!!!!

Four of the Margaretta Elementary students won the North West Ohio Consortium of Coordinators for Gifted (NWOCCG) Scholarships to further their passions or hobbies. The scholarship application included an essay that covered the student hobby or interest, the use of the proposed materials, lessons, experiences, etc. and an itemized budget to spend the $100 if awarded. The students also had to submit two recommendation letters. The winners were 5th graders Jack Wright, programming computers; Zach Gray, playing the banjo; Madison Yontz, singing; and third grader, Renna Keller, taking care of loved ones. These students will present how they used their money to the NWOCCG at a future meeting. Congratulations to these students! Job well done!!
